Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Nonlinear Dynamic Simulation for Prediction of Seismic Ground Motion

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Existing approaches for prediction of seismic ground motion and its associated uncertainties mostly rely on fitting to a recorded motion (usually at the surface) with known earthquake and site characteristics. However, application of such obtained probabilistic ground motion to geotechnical engineering problems, such as free-field probabilistic site response analysis or probabilistic soil-structure interaction analysis, double counts the uncertainties and non-linearities of the soil medium. The goal of this project is to develop a new, physics-based methodology and an attendant computational tool to obtain a complete probabilistic description (probability density function) of site-specific ground motion time-history for a future seismic event by (1) characterizing and quantifying uncertainties in bed-rock motion at a site during future seismic event (right hand side (RHS) uncertainty), (2) characterizing and quantifying uncertainties in site-specific soil properties (left hand side (LHS) uncertainty), and (3) propagating the uncertain bed-rock motion through the uncertain soil. The ability to obtain such probabilistic description of site-specific ground motion time history will not only help in accurately assessing performance of any civil infrastructure object, but also help in critical decision-making process by the project owners, policy makers, and insurance agencies. For example, if the predicted ground motion is too uncertain, then the project owner may ask the following question: what step can be taken to reduce that uncertainty? In answering that question, a process for evaluating the relative contributions of RHS (source and path) and LHS (soil properties) uncertain parameters to overall uncertainty in seismic motions will be demonstrated as well. This will assist the project owners in mobilizing resources for increase understanding of the most significant contributor of uncertainty (source? site? path?), reduce the knowledge uncertainty, and subsequently reduce the overall ground motion uncertainty. In addition, the proposed development of theoretical capability to systematically propagate different sources of uncertainties through the governing equation of mechanics will greatly benefit the empirical modeling community in developing attenuation models especially for the regions where there are limited or no data (for example, eastern United States). Even for western United States, it will help the empirical modelers in better constraining their models. Further, the proposed technique will also provide insight in understanding spatial variation of ground motion and its associated uncertainties (covariance structure), which are under renewed interest in the research community, especially due to their effects on seismic performances of lifeline structures.

This project will combine the state-of-the-art stochastic calculus with the principles of mechanics in developing a finite element based stochastic computational framework to propagate random waves through random non--linear heterogeneous media. It, to best of our knowledge, is the first attempt to simulate wave propagation through nonlinear (elastic--plastic) heterogeneous medium in the stochastic space considering both LHS and RHS uncertainties. Since uncertainties in material properties and external forces are present in all fields of engineering, the impact of this project will be much wider than just in the area of geotechnical engineering. In order to ensure future of developments from this project, high school science and mathematics teachers will be involved (via RET supplement) through summer workshops so that they can transmit their experiences to high school classrooms. The objective here is to emphasize the importance of mathematics and physics in modeling physical phenomena such as earthquake and plant an early seed among the future engineers to seek a career in this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of proposed project is in
combining the state-of-the-art stochastic calculus
with the principles of mechanics to develop
computational methodology, the so called Stochastic
Elastic Plastic Finite Element Method (SEPFEM). The
SEPFEM is used to propagate random/uncertain waves
through random/uncertain non-linear heterogeneous
material. In this particular case, we propagate
earthquekes from the source (uncertain sources,
uncertain location and uncertain magnintudes)
through uncertain rock (deep layers), uncertain
soil (shallower layers), through uncertain, surface
or embedded, structures.

Broader  impact of this research is much wider than
just in the area of geotechnical engineering.
Uncertainty/variability in material properties and
uncertainty in external forces are present in all
fields of engineering. The formulation and
implementation of SEPFEM, and application to
earthquake engineering problems, propagation of
waves from an uncertain source/loading through
uncertain material does address simular problems in
mechanical, biomedical, materials, aerospace as
well as other areas of civil engineering.

Proposed research, to best of our knowledge, is the
first attempt to simulate wave propagation through
nonlinear (elastic--plastic) heterogeneous medium
in the stochastic space considering both left hand
side (uncertain material) and right hand side
(uncertain loads) uncertainties.

Developed SEPFEM will take as input uncertain
material properties, for any elastic or
elastic-plastic material model, given through a
probability density function of a property, and
uncertain lods, given through time histories of
probability density functions, and produce
undertain response, Uncertain response will consist
of probability density functions (PDFs) of
displacements, velocities and accelerations at
nodes of the finite element mesh, as well as
probability density functions of stress and strain
at integration/Gauss points withing finite
elements.

Such obtained PDFs are then used to develop, by
integration, Cumulative Density Functions (CDFs),
also commonly known as fragility curves, that
provide probabilities, in time domain, of, for
example, occurences of failure. Such information is
extremely valuable, as design of an object can be
changed/improved to reduce probability of failure.
In addition to the failure, designer can change the
design so that probaility of undesirable
performance of any of the chosen measures of can be
reduced, using optimal, minimal amount of
resources.

Attached figure illustrates this by showing a
probabilistic cyclic respone of particular soil,
San Francisco Bay mud, where mean response achieves
certain strength. However probabilistic cyclic
response of such material, shown in this figure,
shows that variation of respons within +- one
standard deviation, where 68% of all samples will
be within this range, and variation of response
within +- two standard deviation, where 95% of all
samples will be within this range, can be quite
wide. What this means is that if the designer would
like to ensure that more than 95% of responses
(samples) of her or his object need to satisfy
prescribed strength, this soil will need to be
improved and/or variability reduced. Once this
decission is made, designer can also presribe level
of soil improvement, that will satisfy required
reduction in variability of cyclic shear response.
Upon soil improvement, in situ and laboratory tests
are performed on soil samples in order to assess
variablity and to document PDFs of material
properties of changes soil, so that new
probabilistic cyclic modeling can be performed.
